MainHeading.Title: Supplementary Estimates, 1991. - Vote 34: Industry and Commerce.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I move:

That a supplementary sum not exceeding £2,393,000 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending on the 31st day of December, 1991, for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, including certain services administered by that Office, and for payment of certain loans, subsidies, grants and grants-in-aid.

MainHeading.P: The purpose of this Supplementary Estimate is first, to provide an additional £7.75 million to the IDA, in respect of their capital grants expenditure; and second, to provide an additional £260,000 for the Department's consultancy subhead. The total additional funding required, £8.01 million, is offset by savings on a number of subheads, which, together with increased appropriations in aid, result in a net funding requirement of £2.393 million as detailed in the Supplementary Estimate.

For the year ending 31 December 1991, the IDA were approved a grant-in-aid of £106 million or capital grants. In addition IDA were permitted to avail of £12 million of their own resources made up of grant repayments and reimbursements from the European Social Fund. The IDA's approved expenditure, therefore, for capital grants in 1991 was £118 million.

The IDA require additional funding of £16 million for capital grants in 1991. This has arisen because of the increased level of grant claims in relation to the main grant programmes. The £16 million shortfall on capital grants will be partly met — to the tune of £8.25 million — as follows:
The transfer of £2.75 million additional own resources from building operations to capital grants;
The retention of £3.5 million proceeds from the sale of IDA property which was part of £4.5 million due to be remitted to the Exchequer and which will now be transferred to capital grants;
The realisation of £2 million additional own resources on capital grants from the European Social Fund and from grant repayments.

Over the past few years, there has been a substantially increased level of IDA backed job creation, which has included the attraction to Ireland of a number of major flagship projects in sectors and geographic regions of strategic significance for the IDA's inward investment efforts. These factors combined with an accelerated rate of project development in a number of instances have given rise to the need for increased funding in 1991.

The three-year period of the Programme for National Recovery, 1988-1990, saw an increased activity level, resulting in over 36,000 sustained first time jobs being created with IDA assistance. This represented an increase of 40 per cent over the previous three-year period. At the same time, over the past number of years, there has been a greater focus on achieving greater value for State expenditure. In project negotiation maximum emphasis has been put on achieving sustained long term performance at least cost to the Exchequer. As a result the cost of IDA-backed jobs which have been sustained over a seven-year period fell from £20,097 per job in 1986 to £14,271 in 1990 — measured in constant 1990 prices.

Over the same period — 1986-90 — this allowed the Exchequer capital grant-in-aid to IDA to be reduced from £166.1 million to £110.1 million in constant 1990 prices. Notwithstanding the substantial effort on the part of the IDA in relation to the achievement of value for money, the significantly increased job creation activity since 1988 has led to a short term real increase in IDA capital grant-in-aid requirements. In the medium-term, as the balance between activity levels and the reduction in support for individual projects levels off, the overall funding requirement will recommence its real decline.

The shortfall in grant-in-aid has occurred now because, since 1987, it has been the policy to include a performance clause in every grant agreement, tying payment of grants to fulfilment of job creation targets by companies. Because of the very strong job performance of companies approved for grant support since the introduction of performance clauses, substantial tranches of grants approved to these companies have now become due for payment. In negotiations with companies, IDA always stress that they see the grant agreement as a two-way contract between the company and the Government. Just as companies must fulfil their job commitments, it is, of course, equally important that IDA be in a position to meet their grant payment obligations promptly if they are to maintain credibility with companies.

Since 1988 a number of flagship projects have been approved in sectors of strategic significance for the IDA's inward investment effort. Some of these projects have been significantly large and in a number of cases their investment programme is ahead of schedule. One example of this is the large development at Leixlip for Intel Corporation, the first ever dedicated wafer fabrication plant in Ireland. This investment has been brought forward by one year, and construction of the new 400,000 sq. ft. facility commenced in 1991. The success in attracting this type of facility is invaluable to IDA's marketing efforts in the electronics sector.

The continued efforts to reduce the costs of industrial development in the future are reflected in the implementation of the recommendations of the Triennial Review of Industrial Performance, which my Department published last year. Since 1988, substantial progress has been made in introducing repayable grants in medium-large Irish industry. At the end of 1991, nearly one-third of all financial support approved to this sector was in repayable form. The IDA are confident that, in line with the objective set out in the triennial review, they will be in a position to move by the end of 1993 to a position where 50 per cent of all financial support to medium-large indigenous industry is in the form of repayable, or other remunerating, forms of aid.

The reductions in grant levels recommended in the triennial review in respect of small business and expansions in overseas industry are also being implemented by the IDA. IDA backed companies have made a substantial contribution to job creation in the economy in recent years. Over the three years 1988-90, these firms contributed 18,000 jobs per annum on average towards the national objective of 20,000 jobs a year, which was set down in the Programme for National Recovery.

Despite the difficult environment in 1991, the IDA's target for new first time jobs in manufacturing and international services has been substantially met. In addition, the manufacturing sector as a whole is expected to hold its own and, while other countries are experiencing a decline in the employment contribution of the manufacturing sector, the outlook in Ireland is promising.

The key priority at present must be to address the unemployment problem. Through a combination of prudent Government policy aimed at creating the appropriate fiscal and macro-economic environment and focusing on the achievement and maintenance of international competitiveness at company level, the Irish industrial scene is now in a strong position to move forward. I believe very firmly that, assuming the international economic climate becomes more favourable, we should be able to return to the levels of manufacturing job creation achieved in the 1988-90 period.

However, while the success of that period was built to a significant extent on strong gains in macro-economic competitiveness in our major export markets, in future we are unlikely to be able to rely as much on macro-economic effects. Further gains in competitiveness must, therefore, come from improved performance at industry segment and company level through the more focused development policies being pursued by the IDA.

The projected excess on the consultancy subhead arises primarily because of assignments related to the work of the industrial policy review group which was set up in June, 1991 and the section 14 inquiries which I commissioned into certain aspects of the Greencore and Telecom affairs. While there are some offsetting savings on other elements of the consultancy subhead, an overall excess of £260,000 is projected.

With regard to the industrial policy review group, Deputies will be aware that, last June, I asked a group of leading people from the worlds of industry, business, economic research and trade union affairs to advise on the full range of policies and measures that bear on or influence the development of industry and services here. They had to undertake a fundamental review of a large number of areas of public policy and for that they required independent advice.
The group are now finalising their report and I look forward to receiving it and considering its contents, in the new year.

The first section 14 inquiry relates to Siúicre éireann cpt and certain other named companies forming part of the Greencore Group. I have already made reference to this inquiry, in dealing with questions earlier this afternoon. As Deputies will be aware, the inspector furnished a final report to me on 4 December 1991, which I published on 5 December 1991. On foot of the final report, I decided to continue the restrictions imposed on the Talmino loan note following the interim report and to refer this report also to the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration of possible action. Further possible breaches of company law and fiduciary duties were identified in the report.

The second inquiry relates to Hoddle Investments Ltd. and Chestvale Properties Ltd. I appointed an inspector, under section 14 of the Companies Act, 1990, on 14 October 1991 — replacing an inspector appointed on 1 October 1991 — to investigate and report on the persons who have been financially interested in the success or failure of Hoddle Investments Ltd. and Chestvale Properties Ltd. The appointment arose from concerns which arose from the purchase by Telecom éireann of the former Johnston, Mooney and O'Brien site at Ballsbridge, Dublin, and the recommendations on 1 October 1991 by an inquiry established by the Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications. The fact that there have been so many attempts to disrupt the proceedings of the inspector is a matter of concern. All these actions have been strongly defended, in the public interest, and no effort will be spared to seek to ensure a proper conclusion to this inquiry.

Since these remarks were prepared, the House may be aware that apparently I have to appear before the High Court on Friday, arising out of the last named inquiry, at the instance of Mr. Dermot Desmond to show reasons why I should not be sent to prison.

Speaker.hpid: Acting Chairman (Mr. Boylan) Acting Chairman (Mr. Boylan)
Speaker.P: Let us hope that that does not come about. May I advise Members that because of the severe time constraint this Estimate will have to wind up at 5.45 p.m.? If everybody is to speak, his time is limited.

I am glad to see the Minister is still with us and I hope he will enjoy his Christmas dinner in Limerick if not in Mountjoy. However we will visit him on St. Stephen's Day. We have about 16 minutes remaining so I propose that it is divided equally among my three colleagues, if that should meet the agreement of the House.
Is that agreed? Agreed.

We are not opposing this Estimate. I welcome the Minister's remarks. In the course of his script he emphasised the necessity for competitiveness in Irish industry which he suggested may come about through the more focused development policies being pursued by the IDA and also by being more competitive in our export markets. Last week I put down a Priority Question to be answered by the Minister today. The question asked whether the Minister's Department had conducted an investigation into the possible damage to the competitive position of Irish industry vis-à-vis industries in the United Kingdom following the British Government's decision not to take part in the Social Charter outlined at the Maastricht Summit last week. Some clever person in the Minister's office — I presume that the Minister had nothing to do with it himself — decided that that was a matter for the Minister for Labour and passed it on. I do not think that is very helpful, and I should like the Minister to convey that to his officials. It is clear that the issue of concern is the competitive position of Irish industry, which is the responsibility of the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The criticisms voiced by federations of industrialists were made because of a genuine concern that the Irish position will be damaged because Britain has decided not to agree the Social Charter.

The British Prime Minister on his return from the Maastricht Summit said that he had not signed the Social Charter because it would give British industry a competitive advantage in attracting industry and in exporting to other EC countries. That point has been emphasised by the British delegations for the past six weeks because of their concern about what might come out of the Maastricht Summit. If that were true, then I should have expected the Minister's Department to carry out a study for the Taoiseach, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Finance and whoever else accompanied him to Maastricht, so that the argument could be rebutted or, if it could not be rebutted, Ireland — whose structures of industrial relations are the same as those of the British — could be put on a level footing with Britain and not sign on for the charter at Maastricht.

This is a very serious problem that should have been addressed by the Taoiseach before he went to Maastricht. The Minister's Department should not have availed him of the opportunity to sidestep the issue at Question Time today.

If what the British Government are saying is true, that the Social Charter agreed at Maastricht will put Britain in an advantageous competitive position, then by definition Ireland will be put at more of a disadvantage than will any of the remaining ten EC countries.

MainHeading.P: Precisely what is the Minister and his Department doing to redress the balance in our favour? Of all countries in Europe, Ireland must be competitive — we do not have a population base from which to export, some of our costs are higher than those in other European countries, we are an island, we have peripheral disadvantages and we have a poor transport structure. If Ireland cannot achieve competitiveness within each individual industry, more jobs will be lost.

I am not sure whether the Minister will be able to do so at this stage, but I should have expected him to carry out a study so that the Government would be able to assure Irish industry that the claims made by the British authorities are not correct or, if Britain will have the competitive advantage, the Minister should outline to the House — or to at least bring in different industry sectors and tell them — what he proposes to do to redress the imbalance.

Speaker.P: The Minister for Industry and Commerce is doing his job against the background of one of the highest ever levels of reported growth in GNP. Obviously, such growth is welcome but a great deal of the growth we have already experienced and are likely to experience is in very restricted areas. There has been substantial growth in multinational profits and in profits in the financial services sector. A great deal of that growth has already drained out of the economy. A continuation of the policy of wealthy Irish companies investing the bulk of their profits abroad will deny us the opportunity of benefiting from that growth.

From the figures available it is clear that the Government have no coherent industrial policy aimed at translating growth into wealth retained in Ireland and into jobs for Irish workers. We need radical changes in industrial policy to secure the concept of value added in the Irish economy and to maximise investment in the Irish economy. Without change our economic growth will continue to have more impact on job creation in America, Japan and Germany than here. The improvements in recent years in efficiency, wage moderation and the public finances have all been achieved on the backs of working people. It is time they got their fair share of the benefits. One of the most important, even if medium-term, ways in which the benefits can be shared would be through a radical revamping of industrial policy.

MainHeading.P: The essential failure of the Minister for Industry and Commerce is that he is content to tinker with industrial policy and has avoided any fundamental consideration of the ways in which we create and share wealth. No doubt the Minister is arguing in Cabinet for yet another cut in the top tax rate but the fact that so many people in Ireland are on low or moderate incomes yet are in the higher tax brackets does not seem to be of the same concern.

The Minister has had ample time since 1989 to produce a coherent industrial policy suited to the needs of Ireland in the nineties but, as was illustrated in his speech again today, he goes back to the old cliches. The Minister talks about a policy aimed at creating the appropriate fiscal and macro-economic environment and states that with that the Irish industrial scene is now in a strong position to move forward. If Irish industry were in such a strong position to move forward then the Government would hardly be making provision for social welfare payments for an extra 20,000 or more people during 1992.
The philosophy of the Minister and the Government will not meet the needs of Ireland in this decade. As I have said, a radical revamp is essential.

Speaker.P: The Workers' Party will not be opposing this Estimate either.

Although the Minister has talked about the enhanced efficiency of the IDA and its improved performance in terms of cost per job created and so forth, the fact remains that unemployment is worsening. It has been a singular achievement of the Minister that in the public mind he seems to be preoccupied with protecting what little virtue there is in Government rather than with tackling the unemployment crisis. He has escaped remarkably unscathed from the extent of the crisis that opens in front of us.

MainHeading.P: I am certainly interested in the section of the Minister's contribution dealing with the review body and the report, conclusions and recommendations that will derive from that review. I look forward to them. The review is overdue. It is one straw at which we can grasp in these circumstances. However, I am aware that the Minister has relied on a very orthodox approach to industrial policy and to economic policy generally in the composition and the terms of reference to the review body. He said that expert advice had to be availed of and one would expect that. To my knowledge, however, some of those who have been recruited to assist the review group hold a very traditionalist and orthodox view about the changes needed in industrial policy. I, for one, will certainly be very interested in the work and the findings of the review group.

If Deputy Garland is going to speak I shall have to be very brief but I do have a comment to make about the final chapter of the Minister's contribution, which relates to the efficacy of section 14 of the new Companies Act in so far as it has been applied to the two cases that he instanced. If I heard the Minister correctly, at Question Time today he said that in future he would probably be more inclined, when necessary, to lean towards the invocation of the powers under section 8 of the Act.

Speaker.P: No, the opposite.
Perhaps the Minister would remind me which section gives access to bank accounts, that is the critical issue.
Section 8 does.
That is what worries me.
There is a fault in section 8, is there not?

In the case of Hoddle Investments Limited and Chestvale Properties Limited, without the capacity to follow the money trail we will not get behind that particular scam. It appears to me that the appointment, ab initio, ought to have been under the section of the Act that allowed access to bank accounts. Otherwise we will continue to have the obstruction and arrogance we have experienced in the investigation being conducted. The public demand that this matter be clarified conclusively and satisfactorily. I do not question the Minister's will or commitment, indeed I welcome the last sentence of his introductory remarks to the effect that the public can be assured a proper conclusion to the inquiry but I am honestly very dubious about his ability to provide that if we cannot follow the money trail through bank accounts. Otherwise it will be obstructed as is currently happening.
I would remind Deputy Garland that we are now in the time allowed for the Minister to reply. Does the Minister wish to give way to the Deputy?
I agree to give Deputy Garland one minute, if that is agreeable.
Then, as the House is agreeable, Deputy Garland has one minute.
I thank the Minister for the one minute; it is very little. I will be opposing this Supplementary Estimate.
That is the thanks the Minister gets.

Well, that is the way. I thought Deputy Barry was going to oppose it. I feel I must do so by way of protest at the way the IDA have operated here in recent years. There are signs of a Pauline conversion here. I hope the industrial policy review group will make some recommendations such as that emphasis should be laid now on indigenous industry, preferably with a very high labour content, in an endeavour to solve our unemployment problems. It is generally recognised that the policies of the IDA have not been successful in reducing our levels of unemployment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I might deal first with the point Deputy Peter Barry made in regard to the Maastricht Summit, the fear that we might become less competitive vis-à-vis the United Kingdom. Obviously, that is a fear up to a point but I think we can overcome it. Particularly in terms of the attraction of overseas industry, I will not be shy, if the Lord spares me, about going around the United States and Japan telling them that they should look to Ireland, a full and committed member of the European Community, rather than look elsewhere at a country that is half in and half out of the EC, that not alone has not signed on for its social obligations within the Community but has not signed on for its monetary commitments within the Community. In my humble opinion the British have not strengthened their position either within the Community or in relation to third countries by their less than complete commitment to the EC.
That is as may be.

I suppose I can deal with one other point only in the very short time available to me. I do not think that the problem raised by Deputy Rabbitte about bank accounts is, in practice as large as he might imagine. The right to have access to the accounts — I am now speaking from memory without having notes or the Act before me — comes from section 10, not from either sections 8 or 14. I think section 10 does refer to section 8. A small amendment could make section 10 refer to section 14 as well if it was shown to be necessary. There are some other small amendments we would make also. For example, I would omit the reference in section 8 to the Minister for Justice. I do not know why it is there because it does not seem appropriate. It would be better that one Minister would deal with the matter.

MainHeading.P: I really do not have time now to go into the matters arising out of this section 14 inquiry. As I mentioned earlier, apparently I am now before the courts for my efforts. I want to maintain the right of a Minister who is criticised — perhaps rightly or wrongly; I do not know, but criticised anyway by a person who is subject to investigation — to reply, whether in this House or outside it. I exercised that right and propose to continue to exercise it. I would have thought that my right, as a Minister, to answer such criticism was a matter about which the courts would not concern themselves, that they would see it in the proper sphere. Obviously I cannot pre-judge what will happen on Friday but I want to say here and now that I will continue to exercise my constitutional right, as I think should every Minister and indeed every Member of this House.

Speaker.P: I will now have to put the question.
Is that why the Minister is being summoned, because of his criticism of the decision on Tuesday?
We all support that decision to exercise one's constitutional right.
I must now put the question: “That the Supplementary Estimate be agreed to.”
No, I am opposing it.
In accordance with the Order of the House this morning, the division is postponed until 6.45 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Supplementary Estimates, 1991. - Vote 25: Environment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I move:

MainHeading.P: That a supplementary sum not exceeding £6,000,000 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending on the 31st day of December, 1991, for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for the Environment, including grants to Local Authorities, grants and other expenses in connection with housing, and miscellaneous schemes, subsidies and grants including certain grants-in-aid.

This Supplementary Estimate arises from increased expenditure on Subhead K.3 of my Department's Vote, i.e. grants in respect of non-national roads. It is required for technical reasons only, as the increased roads expenditure is offset by corresponding savings on lottery-funded services elsewhere in the Vote. However, as these savings cannot be applied directly to other services, a Supplementary Estimate is technically needed to cover the increased expenditure on roads. The original voted expenditure total of £598.482 million will not be exceeded.

There are, of course, many issues within my Department's overall sphere of responsibility which I and other Members would be happy to debate in the House but on this occasion we are all governed by Standing Order No. 128 which provides that the debate must be confined to the items contained in the Estimate. I am, proceeding, therefore, on the basis that I am precluded from dealing substantively with issues other than non-national roads.

The provision of £6 million in the Supplementary Estimate is for the construction/improvement of public roads other than national roads, that is the network of regional, county and urban roads. It has always been the case that primary responsibility for the funding of works on these roads rests with the individual local authorities. Traditionally, works on these roads were financed from local resources, with limited grant assistance which, since the early 1970's, was almost exclusively provided through a block grant mechanism. In exceptional cases, special grants were provided for specifically identified improvement works.

In the period up to and including 1988, block grants could be used to supplement expenditure from local authorities' own resources, including the rate support grants, for: (a) maintenance and improvement of regional roads; (b) improvement of county roads (but not maintenance); (c) improvement and maintenance of urban roads; and (d) traffic management measures.

These block grants, together with smaller amounts in western package areas and for road strengthening, came to be referred to as “discretionary grants”, as each local authority was free to decide, within general guidelines issued by my Department, the individual works to be undertaken. In 1989 it was decided to combine the old block grant with the funds available for county road strengthening into a single new system involving a block grant for regional and county roads generally. This was the first time that State road grant assistance was made available for maintenance work on county roads.

Also in 1989 the Government, recognising the deterioration in the condition of non-national roads, especially the regional and county roads, made a commitment that £150 million would be provided over three years in discretionary grants to county councils for these roads. The House is aware that this commitment was more than fulfilled. In fact, total discretionary grants over the period 1989 to 1991 amount to £182.4 million. When account is taken of other grants for non-national roads — special grants and grants to urban authorities — over £220 million will have been provided by the Exchequer for non-national roads in the three years 1989-91. This is an increase of 60 per cent, or over £85 million on the preceding three years.

A good indication of the increased level of funding which has been made available in discretionary grants to county councils can be obtained by comparing the total amount of £23 million paid in 1986 with the £68.13 million being paid this year. This substantial level of funding is a measure of the Government's commitment to the ongoing requirements of the agriculture, forestry and tourism industries in addition to the requirements of rural communities generally. In line with the increased funding every attempt has been made to maximise the extent to which the grants for regional and country roads have been available for spending at the discretion of local authorities themselves.

As an innovation, in 1990 part of the funds available for discretionary grants was used to provide supplementary grants for improvement works by certain authorities which had special road needs in their areas. This approach was continued in 1991.

The operational programme on peripherality maps out the Government's transport strategy for the period 1989-93. Reflecting the vital importance of the national road network to overland transport, the programme provides £511 million for investment in national primary roads. In addition the programme provides for significant investment in non-national roads which are of importance to industry or tourism development. Overall the programme provides just over £60 million for investment in these roads with an EC aid rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities have been afforded considerable discretion in the selection of projects under this sub-programme. Guidelines have been issued by my Department as to the criteria for project selection. It is vital that local authorities respect these since failure to select projects which satisfy the criteria will make it possible to draw down the EC aid available for this purpose. While the aid available for non-national roads is far less than that for national roads, reflecting the greater economic importance of the strategic national road network, it nonetheless has made an important contribution to the increase in resources for such roads in recent years.

The 1991 provision for non-national road improvement grants in subhead K.3 of my Department's Estimate was £61 million. The additional funding of £6 million represents an increase of almost 10 per cent and brings the total to £67 million, all of which has been allocated to local authorities and will be paid out in full by the end of the year, subject to approval by the House of the Supplementary Estimate.

The Government's determination steadily to improve the fabric of the vast network of regional and county roads cannot be questioned in the light of the increased provision for grants in the last few years. But county road maintenance and improvement is a huge undertaking because of the length of road involved — over 87,000 kilometres — the neglect of earlier years and the scale of investment required. Further massive increases in total expenditure, even if we could afford them, are not the answer. Instead we must first ensure that the greatest possible value for money is achieved from the existing expenditure.

None of us can be unaware of the criticisms which have been levelled from time to time at investment in the county road network. For the future we must ensure that to the greatest extent possible Exchequer and local authority investment in these roads is reflected in visible and quantifiable improvements in the network. This may require a new approach to such works and I will be in touch with local authorities about this in the new year.

The abridged Estimates, which were published yesterday, provide for State grants for public roads of £261.48 million in 1992. This is an increase of almost 9 per cent on the already high level of State investment in roads, £240 million, in 1991. It will ensure that sufficient Exchequer capital is provided to draw down all available EC aid. The precise allocation between different types of grants remains to be determined, with the objective of ensuring that expenditure is directed to the areas of greatest need.

In conclusion, I reiterate that the additional expenditure on roads provided for in the Supplementary Estimate is matched by equivalent savings elsewhere in the Environment Vote. The overall expenditure of close on £600 million in the Vote will be in line with the budget estimate, a fact which reflects prudent management of the resources made available to my Department by this House. On this basis I can commend the Supplementary Estimate to the House.

Speaker.P: We will not oppose this Estimate. We welcome any opportunity to improve our non-national roads, which are a source of some dissatisfaction among motorists, tourists and those depending on county roads to get around, people who have broken up their vehicles and have suffered a constant deterioration in county roads due to under-investment.

The figures outlined by the Minister in relation to discretionary grants are correct, but we should not assume that the total amounts of money are increasing. Local authorities are being starved of resources within their own budgets. Because of the cutback in the rate support grant and other changes they are not able to find the necessary resources. While the Minister is giving with one hand, he is taking away with the other. The situation is deteriorating.

As a member of two local authorities and one county council, I can fairly say that the average resurfacing cycle has moved from an acceptable 12 to 14 years to between 27 and 35 years for proper resurfacing. If we continue on these lines, by the end of this period roads will have to be abandoned.

The point has been made that the total amount for the Department is not increasing because of the utilisation of lottery funds. Last Sunday I attended a function organised by the Irish Wheelchair Association who are dependent on the likes of national lottery funding. The Minister is well aware that such voluntary organisations have had their funding decimated by the success of the national lottery. Here we see mainline core funding being substituted by lottery funding. It is taking the bread out of the mouths of people in voluntary organisations. As a general point of principle we are totally opposed to the substitution of lottery funding for mainline Exchequer funding to shore up a shabby, mismanaged budget. That is not what the lottery was instituted for. It was to help provide new services and facilities. It is particularly shameful to see the disabled done down in this way.

MainHeading.P: Referring to value for money, the Minister said a new approach might be required by local authorities and that he would be in touch with them about it in the new year. If that is anything like the contact he had with health boards in relation to value for money, it will raise shudders. Our party support a road audit. There is a variation between county councils as regards value for money. A unit in the Minister's Department or the National Roads Authority should examine this question and pursue it on the basis of getting uniformity of costings for each local authority in respect of road surfacing, restrengthening and so on. Competitive costings should be provided to the Department on an annual basis as part of a road audit and there should be a check-up every two years. There must be a performance element in it. At present local authorities and county councils do not know what is happening in the jurisdiction of other councils and what type of value for money they are obtaining. Only the Department can perform that role.

I wish to refer to the 1991 roads programmes as it relates to national roads. On 6 March, the Minister's predecessor, Deputy Flynn, outlined a very detailed list of projects which would be included in the operational programme for this year. However, it can now be seen that the element in regard to new starts will not be honoured and no work will take place on the Northern Cross route linking the N1 and the N3, that is, the western tollbridge to the airport, no work will take place on the Portlaoise by-pass and no work will take place on the Kilpeddar-Glen o' the Downs route. In the run up to the local elections the former Minister for the Environment, Deputy Flynn, repeatedly gave solemn assurances both inside and outside this House that work would commence on all these projects. This will not now be the case. The Minister's predecessor owes this House, and, in particular me, an apology. The Construction Industry Federation and the Association of National Road Users know only too well what is happening.

I wish to refer to non-national roads. As the Minister is aware, the problem has got so severe that pothole candidates are being elected to public office. Such is their state of derision that county roads have now become an issue on which parties are based. Of course, this is no reflection on the members of Cavan or Monaghan County Councils; it is a reflection on the Government and their failure since 1987 to provide adequate resources. The chickens are now simply coming home to roost. I understand that “The Gay Byrne Show” held a pothole competition. The show was inundated with phone calls from people throughout the country saying the potholes in their area were the worst. This has gone beyond a joke. Legal claims are now being made against local authorities and, as we have heard, litigation liability insurance is becoming a major problem for them.

We have a total road network of approximately 57,000 miles, of which approximately 3,000 miles are non-national roads. The Government need to allocate adequate resources for the upkeep of these roads. This needs to be put in the proper context. The present funding system is not working and local authorities are not able to meet the demands. If the Minister did a trawl of the number of local authority outdoor staff working on roads now and ten years ago he would see that the number would be substantially reduced, even though the mileage with which they have to deal has probably increased.

We need to look at the facts. They are quite clear cut. Nobody has a better case than the road user for State support. The Department of Finance have advised me that the total amount received by way of motor taxation, VAT, excise duties, duties on fuel, etc. was £1,061 million in 1988, £1,221 in 1989 and £1,280 million in 1990. Put simply, this amounts to £3.5 million per day for every day of the year. That is a lot of money. The Exchequer is getting a good deal from the motorist. That is the penalty people who drive a vehicle in this country have to pay. I strongly believe that we need to reorganise the financing of local authority roads.

If the Minister added up the moneys for non-national roads outlined in this Supplementary Estimate they would amount to approximately £131 million. Approximately £80 million will be given in discretionary grants and local authorities will put in approximately £50 million. This comes to a total of £130 million for the maintenance and upgrading of non-national roads. Instead of depending on the road grants system the proceeds from motor taxation — this would be progressive because there is a higher rate of tax for bigger cars — should be put into a fund which would be used for the maintenance of non-national roads. In this way the amount of motor taxation could be increased or reduced in accordance with the national requirement to maintain roads. I want to make it clear that local authorities would have access to this fund on the basis of the road mileage in their area. I understand the proceeds from motor taxation in 1991 will amount to £161 million. This additional £30 million would go a long way towards resolving the problem of potholes. Most of this money could be allocated to local authorities on the basis of mileage and there could be an additional amount for counties Cavan and Clare, which I think have the worst roads in the country. I believe this is the way to proceed.

There is a need for the appointment of a Minister with responsibility for all transport matters. The Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications has no responsibility for ports or shipping. That is the responsibility of the Department of the Marine. This Supplementary Estimate deals with another vital transport issue from the point of view of our economy. We need to take all these matters out of the various Departments and put them into a Department of Transport. Similarly the National Roads Authority should be a national transport authority or a national roads and rail authority. Until we tackle this problem on a piecemeal, ad hoc basis we will not succeed.

I do not know how long the Minister will be in this Ministry — according to some political reports the lifetime of the Government is getting shorter by the day. It is fortunate that someone from the Cavan-Monaghan constituency has taken over as Minister for the Environment. The problem of non-national roads has gone way beyond a joke. I believe this problem will only be resolved in the main by resource allocation, which in turn can only be achieved by a restructuring of the finances. If the Minister has to deal with competing demands such as sanitary services, housing and so on the issue of non-national roads will simply get lost and only the EC element will be looked after. Local authorities will be on the hind tit in trying to carry out their functions in this regard. I ask the Minister to give a commitment to the House that he will make the upgrading of county roads a priority and provide motorists with a proper county road network.

Speaker.P: Within the few minutes available to me I will be mindful of Standing Order 128. However, since this is the last opportunity we will have to comment on the Department of the Environment Estimate for 1991 I want to make one point in relation to housing. The Department of the Environment's performance in relation to housing in 1991 has been nothing short of a disgrace. I described the programme for social housing published in February as a smokescreen to cover the disgraceful lack of a public house building programme. The legislation to give legal effect to elements of that programme such as the shared equity has yet to see the light of day although it was promised to be the law of the land by now. I want to mark the end of this term and the end of the financial year for the Department of the Environment with that cold disgraceful fact. In so far as the primary responsibility for providing shelter is concerned, the Department of the Environment and the Minister have been clearly negligent and have performed abysmally.

MainHeading.P: I want to deal specifically with the Supplementary Estimate before us. Obviously, like other Members of the House, I welcome any additional expenditure on county roads. Those of us who are members of local authorities will know that scarcely a single meeting goes by without a litany of the condition of county roads coming from other members in various counties.

Our national road system has been vastly improved, thank God; I suppose we should more properly thank the EC. Significant regional and structural moneys have been expended to upgrade our national roads and very significant progress has been made in relation to roads with which I am most familiar; for example, in the last six weeks or so the Bray-Shankill by-pass opened and has alleviated one of the worst bottle-necks from south County Dublin into Wicklow. There have also been a number of significant improvements on the N11, the N25 and many other important national link roads.

The national roads amount to some 6 per cent of the total roads network and, for most people living in rural areas, the county and regional road system is of equal — if not of paramount — importance. It links them to their place of business, their local shopping centre and provides the lifeline for many isolated towns. If the county road system is inadequate it simply cuts off some of our towns. As Deputy Yates said, we are not saying anything new to the Minister or to the Leas-Cheann Comhairle in relation to the counties which they represent. In many counties the road system is facing collapse; I know that since the savage cutbacks of 1987 there have been very significant cutbacks in the domestic input to the roads system because, as was pointed out, county roads have been traditionally funded by a mix of contribution from the local authorities' resources — rates money, in other words — and central Exchequer top-up. Unfortunately, there has been a savage cutback in the rate support grant since 1987.

I produced figures to show the Minister a de facto cut of 50 per cent in the rate support grants over the past four years. I will produce the figures again if there is any need to verify them. However, taking inflation into account they are correct. Every local authority are struggling to balance their books and to maintain some semblance of services to people. Many important services have been cut, including refuse collections in rural areas, cutbacks in library and fire brigade services, in essential maintenance repairs and in development works. When it comes to the crunch even services like the county roads must be pared, which has happened. I should like the Minister to produce statistics — it would be a good parliamentary question for the new session — regarding the level of own resources being put into the county road system, county by county, on a comparative basis, for the last five years. In my own county the figures as a percentage of the total have been cut back.

Many counties have tried to maintain a significant local input to the county road system to keep it operable. In a way it seems that the more effort you make the more you are punished in relation to the support grant you get. My county, I have said this in the House before, on the tabulated figures produced this year have the lowest level of support for county roads, pounds per kilometre, of any county in the country. That certainly does not encourage us to continue putting our own resources into it. I hope the Minister is aware of that and will do something about it; he should not punish counties which try to help themselves. One would imagine that the Minister would try to assist those who are struggling, in the face of great adversity, to put some element of their own resources into county roads.

To put the Estimate in context, we are talking about an additional £6 million which, of course, is welcome. However, it is estimated that, to bring roads in my own county up to standard, would cost £8 million, £2 million per year over four years. I am sure that figure could be repeated, probably increased, all over the country. Therefore, the amount of money we are providing tonight would not bring one single county of the 26 up to acceptable standards, which is a dreadful reality.

A number of elements must be addressed. In the national roads plan the element of money to be allocated to non-national roads was signalled to decrease in 1992 and 1993. If that is the case the current bad condition of roads will deteriorate even further. A number of different practices must be carried out on our county roads; the one with which we are most familiar is surface dressing although the Department prefer to call it surface restoration. The surface dressing cycle varies across the country, from 25 to 35 years, which means that if some county roads are black-topped this year they may be expected to get a fresh black-top in 35 years' time. I do not believe that we can expect any road system, particularly as there is increased and growing heavy traffic, to withstand that level of neglect. Most county roads now require extensive patching before we get on to surface dressing which gobbles up scarce resources as well. An even greater resurfacing cycle in years will be evidenced next year unless we put proper resources into them. The notion of surface strengthening is an extremely important element because it is no use putting black-top on roads which are disintegrating underneath. It is an expensive process, costing between £20,000 and £30,000 per kilometre. The reality is that very few kilometres can be strengthened in each county and we are only trying to hold together the fabric of our county roads system in the face of the grants and supports available to us either from our own rates resources or from central Government.

Important work used to be carried out under the heading of special improvement works. They included minor junctions, straightening of bends, clearing of ditches, installation of traffic lights, new footpaths and emergency repairs. Most of these have taken a knock in recent years and the resources which were there, by collective agreement in most councils, to do important small works have now been put on the long finger and precious little important minor improvement works have been carried out.

The total provision for county roads is inadequate. We have said that there are political ramifications as a result; one is the emergence of single issue candidates. There are people seeking public office and focusing exclusively on the issue of county roads. I am not sure that is good for democracy but it is a clear sign of public disquiet at the performance to date of the Government — and the previous Fianna Fáil administration — over the past years in relation to their neglect of county roads. The only way to approach that will be to provide adequate funding. I should like to put a few questions to the Minister because I am a little confused. The Minister informs us that the net £6 million being sought is made up of savings. Perhaps he can indicate to us where those savings were made in his Department in precise terms? Although he informs us in his script that the total net expenditure will be £598.482 million, which was the original adopted figure last year, the Estimate circulated states that the net total figure will be £604.482 million, including the net additional sums. Can the Minister explain? It is probable that the £6 million of expenditure money is simply being absorbed from the national lottery into the Estimate. If that is the case, where was the national lottery fund intended to go? What funding has been sidelined to provide this money tonight?

Lastly, in regard to this additional £6 million, can the Minister specify whether it is a top-up grant to local authorities in addition to the road funding already notified to them for 1991? Can he specify which local authorities will receive the money and the amounts in each case.
In conclusion I signal that the Labour Party will not oppose this net additional expenditure on roads, as they say, a locht a laghad.

Speaker.P: I would like to echo Deputy Howlin's first observation on the Supplementary Estimate when he referred to the biggest problem in the Environment brief at present, which is the appalling situation with regard to housing. The Minister's predecessor was a master of public relations. His greatest public relations achievement was the publication of the so-called plan for social housing which managed to convince many people in the general public that the Government intended to do something to tackle the serious housing problem that now exists. Eleven months later that plan for social housing has been exposed as a fraud and a con on the people on the housing lists, particularly in the run up to the local elections in June. The year 1992 will be one when we will see the social housing problem explode onto the Irish political stage. The build up of frustration relating to housing lists going back to 1987, when the then Fianna Fáil Government effectively ended house building and the provision for social housing will eventually come home to roost next year.

As we are now approaching the break, I would like to ask the Minister to make it his new year resolution to seriously address the social housing problem and to have the promised Housing Bill circulated to us without further delay. I would ask him to give a commitment that he will apply more resources to tackle it than is apparent in the Estimates which were circulated to us this week which, as I read them, provide for nothing more than an as you were situation, essentially the same amount of money as in previous years. There is no carry forward of the unspent amounts from the social housing plan. That will have to be seriously tackled.

The Supplementary Estimate before us concerns non-national roads. It is probably a good time for us to look at that, particularly as we had the commencement of a debate in relation to national roads in the context of a Bill to establish a national roads authority. That Bill will have the effect of making the national roads the cream of our road network and relegating the non-national roads to some kind of a subsidiary limbo situation.

MainHeading.P: It would be churlish not to welcome any additional resources for the improvement and maintenance of non-national roads and for that reason The Workers' Party will not be opposing the Supplementary Estimate before us.

The Minister mentioned in his contribution that the traditional way of funding the maintenance and improvement of non-national roads has been through a combination of funding from the local authorities and special grants from his Department. Previous speakers referred to the fact that there has been a decline in the resources which have been available through the local authorities over the past number of years. This is reflected in the reduction of outdoor staff in local authorities — employees are not there any more to do the normal ordinary maintenance work which is so necessary to keep roads in shape. Neither are the resources available in some local authorities to provide materials for staff when they go out to do their work.

Shakespeare stated that the Devil can quote scripture for his purpose and in this case the Minister is quoting statistics for his purpose. He is conveying an impression in his script that there are percentage increases here, there and everywhere for roads. I am afraid the evidence of this largesse is not to be seen on our roads. As we all know, the physical condition of the non-national roads is deteriorating to the point where it is now one of the standing national jokes. We are rapidly becoming a country of potholed boreens. Road surfaces are disintegrating, the road structure is disintegrating, roads which were built initially for very minimal traffic, which were no more than tarred sheep tracks, are now expected to take much heavier traffic without significant improvement. In many suburban areas of the large urban conurbations roads which were originally country laneways are now meant to serve large urban areas with all of the traffic now generated.

We are now coming into the pothole season. What happens in the pothole season is that the road surface breaks in frosty weather and is then washed away by the showers of rain that follow. Last year, because local authorities did not have the resources to continue to repair those potholes, they were left unrepaired, as a matter of deliberate policy, until the weather improved. There was a view in local authorities that there was no point in repairing a pothole in January because it would have to be repaired again in March. A deliberate policy was adopted that potholes would simply be left unrepaired. The Minister's predecessor capitalised on it last year. In the spring he summoned before him the county engineers and made great public play of the fact that he was instructing them to address the pothole problem, when both he and they knew very well that they would repair the potholes in any case. It was a matter of coincidence that his public instruction to them coincided with the onset of the local elections. We had this marvellous public relations exercise where the county engineers were summoned before the Minister and told to repair the potholes. When it came to the local elections and the fine weather the potholes were repaired. It would appear that they did not do so successfully or that the public relations exercise did not have as much impact in the Minister's own constituency as it would appear to have had in other parts of the country.

I turn now to the question of road improvements. I would echo Deputy Howlin's question as to where the £6 million is going. It was not clear from the Minister's contribution. The Minister conveyed in general terms that it was going to certain local authorities in the form of additional grants. When replying, will the Minister identify the local authorities who will benefit from this and the projects and road improvements to which this extra £6 million will be applied? I do not know if it is the case in relation to my two colleagues, but as a member of two local authorities I do not see any evidence of additional resources being made available.

Indeed, I would draw the Minister's attention to three roads in my constituency for which the Dún Laoghaire Corporation have applied to the Department for funding road improvements over the past couple of years. Wyattville Road has been identified as being the worst road in the local authority area. Wyattville Road, Barnhill Road and Ballinclea Road were formerly rural roads serving small populations but they now have to serve large populations and more traffic due to a large amount of development. Those roads are simply withering away. We have made repeated calls to the Minister and his predecessor to provide resources to enable us to go ahead with improvement schemes on these roads. If my colleague can forgive me for being slightly parochial, I would like the Minister to address this point when he is replying to the debate and to give us some indication that perhaps in 1992 we might be given the resources to carry out the improvement works on these roads.

An area which has been neglected is road safety, particularly the safety of pedestrians. The conditions of footpaths, or the absence of footpaths in many areas, is exposing many people to road injury, particularly the elderly, the disabled and children. In many cases it is preventing citizens from moving about freely. The condition of footpaths is now so bad in many areas that it is simply not safe to walk on them. It is certainly not safe to use them at night, especially if a poor footpath is combined with inadequate lighting. This effectively means that people, particularly elderly people, cannot move about with freedom. I am sure every Member of the House is familiar with footpaths with two inch gaps in them. This is positively dangerous. Because of the reduction in funding the local authorities have not been in a position to repair footpaths, to provide traffic lights or to take other road safety measures. This is something to which the Minister might address himself. Perhaps the time has come for him to provide special grants or to earmark assistance for local authorities to improve footpaths and to provide for pedestrian safety.

If one looks at the rate of casualties on our roads, many casualties are related to the condition of roadways. In the past number of years there has been an average of 500 people a year killed on our roads and 10,000 people a year have been injured — four times the rate of casualties in Northern Ireland. Much of this is due to the appalling condition of the roads. We need to pay a great deal of attention to this. When replying, I would like the Minister to identify where the £6 million is to go and perhaps he would circulate to Members of the House a list of projects which are being funded from this money.

Speaker.P: Deputy Finucane has some four minutes.
I wish the Minister well in his portfolio. I am sure the Minister will concede that he has a daunting challenge ahead of him.

Many of the previous speakers dealt with many of the points I would make. As a member of county council for the last six years, it would be remiss of me if I did not point out some of the difficulties and frustrations which county councils are experiencing. The greatest complaint in any county relates to the condition of the roads, particularly the county roads. One would question whether or not we are even getting value for money. Many of the roadworks undertaken are fire fighting exercises — for instance, what is called tar patching. Engineering staff would point out that quite often filling in potholes with a few shovelfulls of filling is not very successful because when it rains the filling is washed away. I often wonder about the economics of that and whether or not it is a worthwhile exercise at all.

MainHeading.P: Over the past few years most county councils have not got around to addressing the problem of defective footpaths in most towns. That is unfortunate because it leads to a lot of extra public liability claims for councils. One of the most progressive steps taken in recent times has been to use the social employment scheme to maintain footpaths in towns and villages. I hope that county councils will be able to continue to use social employment schemes in future as it is possibly the only solution to the problem unless more local authority finance is provided for this work. We need to do a lot more work in the areas of footpaths because, as Deputy Gilmore pointed out, many footpaths are a hazard to old people, especially in the winter.

Housing is best described as the waiting game, because people who apply for local authority housing have to wait and wait. This has happened because there has been a dramatic cutback in local authority housing over the last few years. The difficult situation was possibly compounded by the withdrawal of the successful reconstruction grants which were available and which were used by many people, particularly younger people, who wished to house themselves. They took over old, often derelict buildings and upgraded them with a certain amount of expenditure topped up by the grant. This took pressure off the local authority. That mechanism is no longer available.

In February we had a sham marketing exercise in relation to the social plan for housing in which there were supposed to be many imaginative proposals to alleviate some of the housing problems. Although the social plan seemed imaginative and appeared in a nice glossy brochure, with booklets being circulated by council offices, at this stage it seems to have been a bit of a smokescreen in order to divert attention from the housing problem. It is ironic for a Minister at the end of the year to state that two transactions have been completed in relation to this whole exercise. I hope the Minister will instruct county councils to proceed with great haste to implement most aspects of what is incorporated in that social plan for housing, because we have a critical housing problem which we will have to address sooner or later. There are many frustrated people who are relying on the local authorities for housing and there is very little incentive for them to try to house themselves.

Speaker.P: I am sorry to interrupt the Deputy, but the time has come to call the Minister to reply.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I thank all the Deputies who have contributed to this debate. In the short space of time available to me I will try to respond to a number of the comments which have been made. The condition of our roads, in particular our non-national roads, impacts daily on everybody who uses them, be it on foot, on a bicycle or in a motor vehicle. As I said in my opening contribution to this debate, the Government are conscious of the state of non-national roads which is evident from their response during the past three years.

In the years 1989-91 a sum of £220 million was spent as against a figure of £85 million during the preceding three year period. In 1986, before we entered Government, £23 million was spent while £68 million has been spent this year. This represents an increase of 196 per cent over that five year period.

It is important that I remind Deputies that responsibility for non-national roads rests with the local authorities who receive a State road grant, which includes the block grant, the road strengthening grant and, sometimes, a special improvements grant.

MainHeading.P: Reference has been made to the eight major road schemes scheduled to begin, under the national primary road network building programme, in the current year. Deputy Howlin gave due recognition to the Minister and the Government for the work which has been done in improving our roads. The Deputy referred specifically to the Shankill by-pass. Work was due to begin on the Dunleer by-pass, the Sweep in Waterford, the Clonee by-pass, the Lucan-Kilcock by-pass, the Mullingar by-pass, the Portlaoise by-pass, phase 1 of the Bray-Shankill road to the Glen of the Downs and the northern cross route in Dublin. Construction is under way at Dunleer, the Sweep, Clonee, Portlaoise and on phase 1 of the Bray-Shankill road to the Glen of the Downs. The Department have approved the acceptance of the tenders for the Mullingar by-pass and for the first of the two main contracts for the Lucan-Kilcock project. The local authorities involved are now finalising the arrangements to get the contractors involved on site. A delay was encountered in the case of the northern cross route but I now expect tenders to be invited for the first main contract early in the New Year. I am satisfied that reasonable progress has been made on these schemes. I have already referred to the fact that there will be a substantial increase in the funding that will be available in 1992.

Deputy Yates suggested that motor tax receipts should be used in maintaining non-national roads. However, he did not say how the Exchequer could make up the difference of £30 million which he suggested should be spent on our non-national roads. As Deputies realise, the Exchequer would have to make up this difference by way of extra taxation, borrowing or cuts in services.

It has been suggested that the local authorities are under-funded. I should point out that local authority current spending is roughly £1,120 million, £503 million of which is met by the Exchequer by way of grants, including the rates support grant. The balance is made up by way of commercial rates — £257 million approximately and other local income — £360 million approximately. There is a limit to the State grants available to local authorities. A balance has to be struck between what the local authorities need and what the country as a whole can afford.

The extra £6 million has already been allocated to the local authorities. In response to Deputy Howlin, I should say that there will not be any supplementary allocation this year over and above that £6 million.

Speaker.P: Who got this money?
I do not have that information but I understand it was allocated in a general way.
Will the Minister send it to us?
Will the Minister circulate it?

In relation to the block grant for improvement and maintenance works, Wexford County Council received exactly the same amount, per kilometre, for non-national roads as every other county, except Dublin where special circumstances exist. However, County Wexford did not receive funds to meet the cost of flood damage to roads as no abnormal damage arose under that heading. Neither did the county receive supplementary improvement grants which were confined to those counties with special difficulties.
The net effect is that we are the worst in the country.

The Deputy's calculation must have been based on the gross amount of discretionary grants, including supplementary grants, and the cost of flood damage. This is not a fair comparison. Deputy Howlin also referred to the net saving. As I explained at the outset this Supplementary Estimate is required for technical reasons. The saving arises as a result of expenditure being less than anticipated on amenity and recreational facilities and on the library service. The funds for these services not spent in the current year will be provided next year.
I am sorry to interrupt the Minister, but his time is up.
Again, I thank all the Deputies who have contributed.
Vote put and agreed to.

As it is now 6.45 p.m. I am required to put the following question in accordance with the Order of the Dáil of this day: “That the Supplementary Estimate for Agriculture and Food for a sum not exceeding £1 million; the Supplementary Estimate for Health for a sum not exceeding £50,438,000 and the Supplementary Estimate for Industry and Commerce for a sum not exceeding £2,393,000 for the year ending 31 December 1991 be hereby agreed to.”
Question put.
The Dáil divided: Tá, 71; Níl, 62.
